pulsars.name: PSR J0610−2100
pulsars.description: The third black widow pulsar discovered, with a 7-hour orbit around an extremely low-mass companion star.
key_facts: 7-hour orbit with an extremely low-mass (≈0.02 M☉) companion star
Distance of 1.5 kpc (4,890 light-years), significantly closer than previous estimates
Shows unique dispersion measure discrepancy due to the Mon R2 H II region

dispersion_measure.explanation: Attributed to thermal plasma along the line of sight not captured by the NE2001 model

interstellar_medium.related_region: Mon R2 H II region at Galactic coordinates (214°, −12.6°)

recommended_visualizations: Binary system showing the pulsar and its low-mass companion
Radiation beaming from the pulsar toward its companion
Map showing the line of sight through the Mon R2 H II region
references: van der Wateren et al. 2022 (emission properties)

pulsars.name: PSR J0030+0451
pulsars.description: A 4.87-millisecond solitary pulsar with a highly significant parallax measurement.
key_facts: 4.87-millisecond solitary pulsar
Precise distance of 0.329 kpc (1,073 light-years)
Transverse velocity of about 15 km/s
recommended_visualizations: Pulsar position relative to the local stellar neighborhood
Proper motion vector diagram

pulsars.name: PSR J0621+1002
pulsars.description: A 28.85-millisecond pulsar in an 8.3-day orbit with a companion, notable for its high systematic errors that were reduced through 1D interpolation techniques.
key_facts: 28.85-millisecond pulsar in 8.3-day orbit
Distance of 1.6 kpc (5,200 light-years)
Transverse velocity of about 20 km/s
recommended_visualizations: Binary system configuration
Benefits of 1D interpolation for astrometric precision

pulsars.name: PSR J1012+5307
pulsars.description: A 5.26-millisecond pulsar in a binary system with a white dwarf companion, important for tests of gravitational theories.
key_facts: 5.26-millisecond pulsar in a 0.6-day orbit with a white dwarf companion
Distance of 0.877 kpc (2,860 light-years)
Used to constrain alternative theories of gravity
recommended_visualizations: Binary system configuration with white dwarf companion
Comparison with Gaia observations of the companion

pulsars.name: PSR J1024-0719
pulsars.description: A 5.16-millisecond pulsar with an extremely high transverse velocity, theorized to be in an ultra-wide orbit with a companion star.
key_facts: 5.16-millisecond pulsar with extremely high space velocity (~300 km/s)
Likely ejected from a dense stellar region
May be in an ultra-wide orbit with a companion

unusual_properties.negative_period_derivative: Probably due to acceleration induced by a far-away companion
unusual_properties.high_velocity: ~300 km/s, 3σ above the mean for MSPs

pulsars.gaia_consistency: Highly consistent between VLBI and Gaia measurements, strengthening the ultra-wide binary hypothesis
recommended_visualizations: Comparison with typical MSP space velocities
Hypothesized ultra-wide binary configuration

pulsars.name: PSR J1518+4904
pulsars.description: One of only two double neutron star (DNS) systems in the current sample, with a highly significant parallax measurement.
key_facts: 41-millisecond pulsar in a double neutron star system
40σ parallax measurement - the most significant for any DNS
High ecliptic latitude of 63° (timing parallax would take ~600 years)

orbital_characteristics.inclination_constraint: sin i ≤ 0.73 at 99% confidence level (from non-detection of Shapiro delay)

astrometric_properties.timing_parallax_note: Would take approximately 600 years to detect

recommended_visualizations: Double neutron star orbital configuration
Probability distribution for inclination angle
Comparison of VLBI parallax vs timing parallax methods

pulsars.name: PSR J1537+1155
pulsars.description: The second double neutron star system ever discovered, with exceptionally high proper motion and a stringent test of General Relativity.
key_facts: Second double neutron star system ever discovered
Exceptionally high proper motion among all Galactic DNS systems
Used for precise orbital decay tests of General Relativity
pulsars.proper_motion: Exceptionally high compared to other Galactic DNS systems

general_relativity_test.orbital_decay_ratio: 0.96 ± 0.02 (ratio of intrinsic orbital period decay to GR-predicted decay)

pulsars.limitations: Distance precision remains the limiting factor for GR tests
recommended_visualizations: Double neutron star system orbital visualization
Contributions to orbital period decay diagram
Graph showing agreement with General Relativity predictions

pulsars.name: PSR J1640+2224
pulsars.description: A 3.2-millisecond pulsar in a wide 175-day orbit with a white dwarf companion.
key_facts: 3.2-millisecond rotation period
Wide 175-day orbit with a white dwarf companion
Consistent measurements across different astrometric techniques

astrometric_measurements.results: Highly consistent across quasi-VLBI-only results and VLBI + timing results

recommended_visualizations: Binary system with pulsar and white dwarf companion
175-day wide orbit diagram
The four possible orbital orientations

pulsars.name: PSR J1643−1224
pulsars.description: A 4.6-millisecond pulsar showing significant interstellar medium effects including scattering and scintillation.
key_facts: 4.6-millisecond rotation period in a 147-day orbit with a white dwarf companion
Shows significant temporal and angular broadening due to interstellar medium effects
Associated with the HII region Sh 2-27 as its main scattering screen

interstellar_medium_effects.temporal_broadening: 5 μs at 1 GHz (varies on yearly timescale)
interstellar_medium_effects.frequency_scaling: τsc ∝ ν^-3.9 (close to Kolmogorov turbulence model)

hii_region.name: Sh 2-27
hii_region.association: Independently confirmed as the main scattering screen

scattering_screen_distance.method: Derived from angular broadening and temporal scattering relationship

recommended_visualizations: Pulsar system with multiple scattering screens
Temporal broadening of pulse profiles
Earth-screens-pulsar geometry with the HII region Sh 2-27

pulsars.name: PSR J1721−2457
pulsars.description: A 3.5-millisecond solitary pulsar discovered at intermediate Galactic latitudes with significant interstellar scattering effects.
key_facts: 3.5-millisecond solitary pulsar at intermediate Galactic latitudes
Secondary phase calibrator heavily resolved due to interstellar medium scattering
Non-detection of parallax likely due to refractive image wander

astrometry.parallax: Non-detection, (likely due to refractive image wander)

observational_challenges.calibrator_issues: Main secondary phase calibrator is heavily resolved due to IISM scattering
observational_challenges.baseline_problems: Non-detections on the longest baselines and lack of calibration solutions for some antennas
observational_challenges.resolution_impact: Reduced spatial resolution of VLBI observations
observational_challenges.refractive_effects: Refractive image wander as the line-of-sight to the pulsar changes

recommended_visualizations: Effects of interstellar scattering on pulsar observations
Diagram showing refractive image wander phenomenon
Illustration of calibration challenges in VLBI observations

pulsars.name: PSR J1730−2304
pulsars.description: A solitary 8.1-millisecond pulsar notable for being the least-energetic gamma-ray pulsar discovered, helping define the death line for neutron star high-energy radiation.
key_facts: 8.1-millisecond solitary pulsar
Least-energetic gamma-ray pulsar discovered so far
Helps define the death line for neutron star high-energy radiation

emission_properties.death_line: Refined the gamma-ray emission death line for all pulsars

pulsars.scientific_significance: Plays a key role in exploring the death line of neutron star high-energy radiation
recommended_visualizations: Graph showing the gamma-ray pulsar death line with this pulsar highlighted
Visualization of the pulsar's energy output compared to other gamma-ray pulsars
Pulsar position in the P-Pdot diagram highlighting its near-death-line status

pulsars.name: PSR J1738+0333
pulsars.description: A 5.85-millisecond pulsar in a 8.5-hour orbit with a white dwarf companion, important for testing alternative gravitational theories.
key_facts: 5.85-millisecond pulsar in a 8.5-hour orbit with a white dwarf companion
Key system for constraining alternative gravitational theories
Tests predictions of dipole gravitational radiation

parallax_measurements.vlbi_only: 2.3σ away from the most precise timing parallax

scientific_importance.gravitational_theories: Plays a leading role in constraining alternative gravitational theories that predict dipole gravitational radiation
scientific_importance.parallax_implications: True parallax value has implications for white dwarf radius, neutron star mass, and gravitational wave predictions

recommended_visualizations: Binary system with pulsar and white dwarf companion
Diagram illustrating tests of alternative gravitational theories
Comparison of different parallax measurement methods

pulsars.name: PSR J1824−2452A
pulsars.description: A 3-millisecond solitary pulsar discovered in the globular cluster M28 (NGC 6626), with proper motion suggesting it remains bound to the cluster.
key_facts: 3-millisecond solitary pulsar in globular cluster M28 (NGC 6626)
Transverse velocity of 28 ± 20 km/s, less than the cluster escape velocity
Likely bound to M28 as expected

observational_challenges.calibrator_issues: Best in-beam phase calibrator was both resolved and faint (3.3 mJy)
observational_challenges.consequence: Noisy solutions, especially on the longest baselines, likely causing parallax non-detection

recommended_visualizations: Position of the pulsar within M28 globular cluster
Vector diagram showing proper motion relative to the cluster
Illustration of the pulsar's binding to the cluster

pulsars.name: PSR J1853+1303
pulsars.description: A 4.09-millisecond pulsar in a 116-day orbit with a white dwarf companion.
key_facts: 4.09-millisecond pulsar in 116-day orbit with white dwarf companion
Orbital inclination of approximately 85° based on Shapiro delay
Distance of about 2.0 kpc (6,520 light-years)
pulsars.calibrator_issues: Main calibrator shows jet structure that may contribute to astrometric uncertainties
recommended_visualizations: Binary system configuration showing high inclination
Shapiro delay measurements visualization
references: Faisal Alam et al. 2021 (Shapiro delay measurements)

pulsars.name: PSR J1910+1256
pulsars.description: A 4.98-millisecond pulsar in a 58.5-day orbit with a companion.
key_facts: 4.98-millisecond pulsar in 58.5-day orbit
Disparity between VLBI and timing proper motion measurements
Possible Gaia counterpart candidate with inconsistent proper motion
pulsars.calibrator_issues: Main calibrator shows jet structure at ~45° position angle
pulsars.gaia_association: Proposed Gaia counterpart remains inconclusive due to proper motion discrepancies
recommended_visualizations: Binary system configuration
Comparison of VLBI, timing, and Gaia proper motion vectors

pulsars.name: PSR J1911-1114
pulsars.description: A 3.63-millisecond pulsar in a 2.7-day orbit with a companion.
key_facts: 3.63-millisecond pulsar in 2.7-day orbit
No published timing parallax
Lower limit of distance approximately 1.3 kpc
recommended_visualizations: Binary system configuration
Proper motion vector diagram

pulsars.name: PSR J1918-0642
pulsars.description: A 7.65-millisecond pulsar in a 10.9-day orbit with a companion.
key_facts: 7.65-millisecond pulsar in 10.9-day orbit
Significant improvement in parallax precision when using timing priors
Distance of about 1.48 kpc (4,825 light-years)
pulsars.astrometric_note: 42% improvement in parallax precision when using timing priors (the most significant improvement in the sample)
recommended_visualizations: Binary system configuration
Demonstration of parallax precision improvement

pulsars.name: PSR J1939+2134
pulsars.description: A 1.56-millisecond pulsar, the brightest MSP in the northern hemisphere, which was used as a secondary phase calibrator in inverse 1D interpolation.
key_facts: 1.56-millisecond solitary pulsar, brightest MSP in northern hemisphere
Used as a secondary phase calibrator in inverse 1D interpolation
Distance of about 2.9 kpc (9,455 light-years)
pulsars.astrometric_note: 36% improvement in parallax precision when using timing priors
pulsars.special_technique: Inverse-referenced 1D interpolation using this pulsar as the in-beam calibrator
recommended_visualizations: Inverse 1D interpolation technique diagram
Pulsar brightness compared to other MSPs
